But in a eouncil of all Gaul held ut Bibracte the national hero was confirmed in his position by a unanimous vote of the people. lle pursued his old tactics of avoiding a general engagement end trying to starve the Romans out of the country, but at the same time he supplied them with an additional motive for leaving by organizing attacks upon the Prnvince. These were resisted partly by the provincials themselves and partly by Lucius Caesar with twenty-two cohorts, who was acting as lieutenant to his cousin. The Proconsul himself, blocked by the Gauls from communication with the Province and Italy, sought aid from beyond the Rhine, and reinforoed himself with that mixed cavalry and infantry of the Germans, which he regarded as so effective. Acting on the principle of assigning the best instruments to the best performers, Caesar substituted the horses of his own officers for the poorer animale that these allies had brought with them. The success which awaited him may be traced in grem measure to this piece of wisdom, since on subsequent critical occasions it was the Germana who decided the fate of the day.

One of the most remarkable things in the story of the Gallic war is the surprising turn of fortune that now followed Caesar was in full retreat to the Province, being somewhere on the border between champagne and F rauche Comte (66, § 2), when Vercingetorix encamped within ten miles of him. So confident were the Gauls in the superiority of their cavalry that the knights bound them selves by a solemn vow not to return to their homes till they had ridden twice through the ranks of the enemy. Nevertheless, the Gallie cavalry were utterly defeated, chiefly by the aid nf the Germans, and Vercingetorix, despain'ng of holding the field, shut himself up in the hill-fortress of Alesia.
